article_title: William Galston: 'Secular Stagnation' May Be for Real
article_text: The U.S. has an economic growth problem, and it started before the Great Recession. Between 1949 and 2000, Third Way's Jim Kessler calculates, the annual rate of growth exceeded 3% a total of 34 times—two years out of every three. During the eight Clinton years, growth reached 4% five times and fell below 3% only twice. Since 2000 growth has reached 3% just two times and did not reach 4% at all, even during 2003-07, the peak years of the recovery from the 2001 recession. Since the beginning of the recovery from the Great Recession of 2008-09, annual growth has not yet reached 3%, and 2014 looks to be no exception....

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, William A. Glaston writes that low interest rates haven't ignited growth. Raising the target inflation rate is worth consideration.
twitter.title: 'Secular Stagnation' May Be for Real

article_summary:
The U.S. has an economic growth problem, and it started before the Great Recession.
Since the beginning of the recovery from the Great Recession of 2008-09, annual growth has not yet reached 3%, and 2014 looks to be no exception....
During the eight Clinton years, growth reached 4% five times and fell below 3% only twice.
Between 1949 and 2000, Third Way's Jim Kessler calculates, the annual rate of growth exceeded 3% a total of 34 times—two years out of every three.
Since 2000 growth has reached 3% just two times and did not reach 4% at all, even during 2003-07, the peak years of the recovery from the 2001 recession.
